div.p: Hi, my name is Alice Begley, and I'm a financial aid counselor here at DeSales University.
In order to get started with the financial aid process, the first thing you need
to do is complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid.
It's also known as the FAFSA.
Go to www.fafsa.ed.gov to complete this process.
When you complete your FAFSA, you will need you tax information from the current year.
So if we're filing the 2010-2011 FAFSA, you would need your taxes from 2009.
When this process is completed we will get the information from the Federal government,
which will give us an EFC-an Estimated Family Contribution.
This is what we use in order to package you with scholarships or grants.
You will also need to go to www.studentloans.gov to complete your Master Promissory Note
and entrance counseling for your student loan.
We are going with direct loans now, so we go directly to the Dept.
of Education.
In the ACCESS program, it is divided into trimesters.
We have the Fall Trimester, the Spring Trimester, and the Summer Trimester.
You must be enrolled in at least six credits in each trimester to receive financial aid.
In order to receive the Pennsylvania State Grant, you need to be enrolled
in every session in every trimester.
Your FAFSA would need to be filed by May 1st of each year in order
to be considered for the state grant.
The way we figure your financial aid, is we create a budget for you.
You take your tuition, with books, and living expenses-that would be your budget.
Then we subtract your Estimated Family Contribution to come up with your need.
Then your loans are based on your need.
If you're eligible for a Pell Grant, that will be deducted
from your need, along with your state grant.
If you have any need left, that would make your loan go into the subsidized category.
If you don't have need, it will go into unsubsidized.
As an independent student, you would be eligible for both subsidized and unsubsidized loans.
If you drop any classes in your trimester-six credits is part time,
12 credits is full time-if you want to drop any
of your classes it could impact your financial aid.
So you should really contact your advisor
or the financial aid office before you drop a class to see how this would impact.
If you have any additional questions, you can call our office
at 610-282-1100 extensions 1287 or 1449.
You can contact us through e-mail at finaid@desales.edu.
And, good luck!
